tourBios.curYrHigh: Was the 18- and 36-hole leader at the Mississippi Gulf Resort Classic in early April but finished second to Miguel Angel Jimenez after a late charge by Jimenez, who closed with an 8-under-par 64. Finished T10 at the Allianz Championship, the first full-field event of the year...One week later, was T3 at the Chubb Classic where his final-round 70 included a pair of eagles on Nos. 3 and 13.
tourBios.carHigh:
Member of the Web.com Tour in 1990, 1998 and 2003-11. Member of the PGA TOUR in 1996-97 and 1999-2002 and 2012. 

2012: Made the cut in nine of 20 starts on the PGA TOUR, highlighted by three top-25 finishes...Claimed a pair of top-20s in two of his last three TOUR starts...Produced his second PGA TOUR hole-in-one when he aced the 183-yard No. 7 at Montreux G&CC. Used a 7-iron in the first round at the Reno-Tahoe Open. Finished a season-best T21...Fired a career-low 63 in the second-round of the Frys.com Open. Hit every green on the back and had nine birdie putts. Made seven for a score of 29. Went on to T16, his best finish of the year...Netted two top-10 finishes in 11 starts on the Web.com Tour...Was among eight players tied for the first-round lead at the Chiquita Classic and eventually posted his best Web.com Tour performance of the year when he shot 66-68 on the weekend at The Club at Longview to finish T5. 

2011: Saw action in 22 events but only had three top-25 finishes among eight made cuts...Set a personal and course record with an 11-under-par 60 in the second round of the Midwest Classic. Was only three strokes back of co-leaders J.J. Killeen and James Nitties but a third-round 73 dropped him back in the pack to a T25 finish. 

2010: Played in 26 events and made 15 cuts with three top-10 finishes. Finished No. 76 on the money list. Opened the year with a T9 finish at the Michael Hill New Zealand Open...Had a roller-coaster week at the Stadion Athens Classic but still posted his second top-10 of the year. After going into the weekend at even-par and tied for 38th, strong play helped him improve to T10...His next top-10 was 16 starts later at the Chattanooga Classic, where he was T5 after posting four under-par rounds. 

2009: Made the cut in half of his 25 Web.com Tour starts, with his best finish a T17 at the Knoxville Open. 

2008: Made the cut in 12 of 27 starts on the Web.com Tour and earned his second career title with a come-from-behind win at the season-opening Panama Movistar Championship. Shot a 1-over 71 in the final round to overcome a two-stroke deficit at Panama GC. Held a three-stroke lead after the second round. 

2007: Finished No. 76 on the Web.com Tour money list, with $79,830...Made the cut in 17 of 26 starts, tallying nine top-25 finishes but failing to crack the top 10 in any tournament. 

2006: Made the cut in 13 of 26 starts on Tour, including three top-10 finishes. His first was a T10 at the Price Cutter Charity Championship in Springfield, Mo...Completed the season No. 56 on the money list, with $112,559. Sitting in the No. 89 spot on the money list with just six regular-season events remaining on the schedule, put together back-to-back impressive finishes at the Albertsons Boise Open (fourth) after holding the first-round lead with a 63. He later was fifth at the Oregon Classic, helping secure his spot in the season-ending Web.com Tour Championship at The Houstonian. Finished the year ranked No. 4 in Greens in Regulation Percentage (71.5). 

2005: Made the cut in seven of 22 starts, with a T14 at the Oregon Classic his best finish. Posted a T6 at the weather-shortened, 54-hole BellSouth Classic after Monday-qualifying for the PGA TOUR event. It was his first top-10 on the PGA TOUR since a T10 at the 2002 Michelob Championship at Kingsmill. The T6 was his best finish on TOUR since a T3 at the 2000 PLAYERS Championship. 

2004: Made the cut in six of 11 starts on the Web.com Tour. Finished the season with two top-25 finishes. Ranked No. 58 on the final money list, with $103,738. Broke through for his first career Tour victory at the Mark Christopher Charity Classic. Rounds of 65-69-72-66 left him with a winning total of 12-under-par 272, three shots ahead of Bubba Watson and Scott Gutschewski. Collected $81,000 for the win. Only other top-10 finish came at the Samsung Canadian PGA Championship (T6). 

2003: Finished T4 at the Samsung Canadian PGA Championship for his only top-10 of the Web.com Tour season. Finished T74 at the BellSouth Classic in his only PGA TOUR event of 2003. 

2002: Finished No. 189 on the PGA TOUR money list, with $144,454. Made the cut in seven of 30 tournaments. Finished T10 for season-best $88,800 at the Michelob Championship at Kingsmill for his only finish inside the top 10 all season. 

2001: Was able to retain exempt status, thanks to three top-15s early in the season. Best effort of the season, a T11, came at BellSouth Classic at TPC Sugarloaf, where he owns a home on the grounds. 

2000: Enjoyed a breakthrough year on the PGA TOUR. Recorded personal bests in season earnings/rankings ($1,040,244/44th), top-10 finishes (five), top-25 finishes (12) and cuts made (23). Best showing of the year came at THE PLAYERS Championship, where rounds of 73-70-71-70 produced a T3 and his season's best earnings of $270,600. First-round, 6-under-par 66 at PGA Championship shared the lead with Tiger Woods and paved the way for his best showing in a major. Stood one stroke behind Woods after both the second and third rounds, before a final-day 75 resulted in T9. 

1999: Broke into top 100 on the money list for the first time in career. In second appearance of the year, finished T3 at Doral-Ryder Open. Posted first top-10 in a major with a T10 at British Open. Gained exemption by finishing second on 1998-99 Southern Africa Tour order of merit. Played on Southern Africa Tour in January and February, winning the Dimension Data Pro-Am and was runner-up at South African Open Championship. Won Peru Open in November and Argentine Open in December. 

1996: Finished among top 125 for first time on the PGA TOUR. Best finishes were T3 at Bell Canadian Open and T9 at LaCantera Texas Open. Won the Litoral Open in Argentina. 

1995: Made his mark in international competition during the season, winning the South Africa Masters and the Canadian Masters. At the Canadian Tour event, he won by 10 strokes...Finished second on the order of merit and led that circuit in scoring average. 

1994: Won the Manitoba Open. 

1990: Made the cut in seven of 16 tournaments during the inaugural season of the Web.com Tour. Was T9 at the Gateway Open was best of three top-25 finishes.
tourBios.otherCarHigh: Sister, Page, is former LPGA member and former women's golf coach at Vanderbilt…Enjoys discussing politics…Was valedictorian of his high school graduating class. Lists former President Ronald Reagan as his hero…Got his start in golf from his dad at age 8…Attended Sarasota High School…Bucket list includes attending the World Cup…Favorite quote is "Often wrong, seldom in doubt." Would love to guest host "Squawk Box" on CNBC…Has won professional events in six countries.

tourBios.intlVics: (9): 1994 Manitoba Open [Can]. 1995 South Africa Masters [SAf], Canadian Masters [Can]. 1996 Litoral Open [de las Americas]. 1998 Peru Open [de las Americas]. 1999 Dimension Data Pro-Am [SAf], Peru Open [de las Americas], Argentine Open [de las Americas]. 2000 Peru Open [de las Americas].
tourBios.curYearHigh: Was the 18- and 36-hole leader at the Mississippi Gulf Resort Classic in early April but finished second to Miguel Angel Jimenez after a late charge by Jimenez, who closed with an 8-under-par 64. Finished T10 at the Allianz Championship, the first full-field event of the year...One week later, was T3 at the Chubb Classic where his final-round 70 included a pair of eagles on Nos. 3 and 13.
tourBios.carHigh:
Member of the Web.com Tour in 1990, 1998, 2003-11 and 2013. Member of the PGA TOUR in 1996-97 and 1999-2002 and 2012. 

2013: Made the cut in 10 of 22 Web.com Tour starts and had six top-25 finishes and three top-10s...At the season-opening Panama Claro Championship, finished T4, challenging for the lead but falling short of becoming the oldest winner in Tour history. Just six months shy of his 50th birthday, was within two of the lead after 15 holes Sunday but stumbled with a bogey and two pars down the stretch...Finished T6 at the Brasil Classic in Sao Paulo, where he fired a 6-under 65 in the final round...Added another T6, at the Mid-Atlantic Championship in early June, which moved him to No. 25 on the money list...Made the cut in one of four starts during the Finals, with a T17 at the Chiquita Classic his top showing. 

2012: Made the cut in nine of 20 starts on the PGA TOUR, highlighted by three top-25 finishes…Claimed a pair of top-20s in two of his last three TOUR starts…Produced his second PGA TOUR hole-in-one when he aced the 183-yard No. 7 at Montreux G&CC. tourBios.personal: Sister, Page, is former LPGA member and former women's golf coach at Vanderbilt...Enjoys discussing politics...Was valedictorian of his high school graduating class. Lists former President Ronald Reagan as his hero...Got his start in golf from his dad at age 8...Attended Sarasota High School...Bucket list includes attending soccer's World Cup...Favorite quote is "Often wrong, seldom in doubt." Would love to guest host "Squawk Box" on CNBC...Has won professional events in six countries.

tourBios.otherVics: (9): 1994 Manitoba Open. 1995 South Africa Masters, Canadian Masters. 1996 Litoral Open. 1998 Peru Open. 1999 Dimension Data Pro-Am, Peru Open, Argentine Open. 2000 Peru Open.
tourBios.curYearHigh: Was the 18- and 36-hole leader at the Mississippi Gulf Resort Classic in early April but finished second to Miguel Angel Jimenez after a late charge by Jimenez, who closed with an 8-under-par 64. Finished T10 at the Allianz Championship, the first full-field event of the year...One week later, was T3 at the Chubb Classic where his final-round 70 included a pair of eagles on Nos. 3 and 13.
tourBios.carHigh:
2015: Among the top-10 finishers a total of 10 times in 22 appearances, and season was highlighted by a pair of runner-up performances...In early August, was in contention throughout the 3M Championship and eventually T2 at TPC Twin Cities, his best PGA TOUR Champion effort since finishing second at the 2014 Quebec City Championship. Opening-round 67 included a run of seven consecutive birdies (Nos. 17-5), matching the tournament record and one shy of the PGA TOUR Champions all-time record...In October, was in the mix again midway through the San Antonio Championship before finishing second, three strokes behind Bernhard Langer. Was tied with Langer until a three-putt bogey at the 16th hole just moments before Langer birdied the 15th to open a two-stroke cushion. Runner-up check pushed his single-season earnings over the $1-million mark for a second straight year on the PGA TOUR Champions...Closed with a 6-under-par 64, matching his best closing-round score on Tour, to T3 at the Shaw Charity Classic...Posted three consecutive rounds in the 60s at The ACE Group Classic, with just one bogey over his 54 holes to finish fourth in Naples...Was also T7 at the U.S. Senior Open when he had rounds of 68-69 on the weekend at Del Paso CC...Used rounds of 68-68 on the weekend to T8 at the Dick's Sporting Goods Open...Shot the low round of the tournament, a 7-under 65 Saturday, at the Mississippi Gulf Resort Classic to T9 near Biloxi...Repeated his feat in Mississippi, one month later outside Houston, shooting the low round of the event, a 7-under 65 Saturday, to eventually T9 at the Insperity Invitational...Was also T9 at the SAS Championship in October.
2014: Earned Rookie of the Year honors on the PGA TOUR Champions, thanks to a victory and a pair of second-place finishes all within a four-event stretch in the latter third of the season. Earnings of $1.1 million were a personal best, surpassing his 2000 PGA TOUR season ($1,040,244)...Highlight of his year came in August when he defeated Mark Brooks in a one-hole playoff at the Boeing Classic near Seattle. Jumped into the second-round lead following a 9-under-par 63 Saturday and led by as many as three strokes on the back nine Sunday before a late charge by Brooks, who birdied six of his final seven holes. After missing a 10-foot birdie opportunity on the 54th hole, he ended the playoff on the first extra hole after hitting a dramatic 3-wood second shot from 245 yards on the par-5 18th to within six feet of the flag, setting up a tap-in birdie. The win at TPC Snoqualmie Ridge came in his 16th start on the PGA TOUR Champions, and ended a victory drought of over six years—since a title in Panama on the Web.com Tour. Earned a check for $300,000, the largest of his career...Two weeks after winning the Boeing event, almost won again in Quebec City. Eagled the last hole to appear to earn at least a playoff spot but saw Wes Short, Jr., finish fast with a birdie-birdie-eagle run to edge him by a stroke at the Quebec Championship...His strong play continued in his next outing in Hawaii two weeks later. Had birdies on six of his first 12 holes Sunday to take the lead at one point at the Pacific Links Hawai'i Championship. However, a bogey at No. 13 would prove costly and lead to an eventual T2 finish with Fred Funk, one stroke behind Paul Goydos...In just his third start on the circuit, was one of several players atop the leaderboard late in Sunday's final round at the Toshiba Classic but saw his chances derailed when he made bogeys at Nos. 14 and 17 and finished T5 at Newport Beach...Was also T6 at The Senior Open Championship despite carding a Sunday 75. Moved up the leaderboard at Royal Porthcawl with a third-round 65...Also T9 at the U.S. Senior Open after being one stroke off the 36-hole lead at Oak Tree National...In early March, travelled to Chile to compete in the Web.com Tour's Chile Classic but missed the cut after rounds of 73-72 in Santiago...Made just the third hole-in-one in the history of the Nature Valley First Tee Open at Pebble Beach when his sand-wedge shot from 103 yards went in the hole at the par-3 seventh in the final round. Ace was also the third of his TOUR career (had two on the PGA TOUR) and was the ninth on the Champions Tour in 2014. 

2013: Open-qualified for the AT&T Championship, the Champions Tour's final full-field tournament. Finished T15 in San Antonio...Had 22 starts on the Web.com Tour with a trio of top-10 finishes to his credit...Two of those came in his first four starts when he was T4 at the Panama Claro Championship and T6 at the Brasil Classic...Other top-10 effort came in June's Mid-Atlantic Classic...Earned fully-exempt status for the Champions Tour in 2014 by virtue of his fourth-place finish at the National Qualifying Tournament at TPC Scottsdale in November. Closed with a 1-over-par 73, and was one of five players to finish T4 through 72 holes Friday. Returned to the course on Saturday morning and secured one of the two remaining fully-exempt positions when he made par on the first playoff hole.
tourBios.otherCarHigh: A member of the Web.com Tour in 1990, 1998, 2003-11 and 2013. Member of the PGA TOUR in 1996-97, 1999-2002 and 2012...Enjoyed his finest season on the PGA TOUR in 2000 when he made 30 starts and finished 44th on the money list with $1,040,244, a personal career best in earnings. Posted five top-10 finishes, a dozen finishes in the top 25. His best showing of the year came at THE PLAYERS Championship, where rounds of 73-70-71-70 produced a T3 and a career best earnings of $270,600. A first-round, 6-under-par 66 at PGA Championship shared the lead with Tiger Woods and paved the way for his best showing in a major. Stood one stroke behind Woods after both the second and third rounds, before a final-day 75 resulted in T9...PGA TOUR career also includes third-place finishes at the 1999 Doral-Ryder Open and at the 1996 Bell Canadian Open...Was a two-time winner on the Web.com Tour. Won the 2004 Mark Christopher Charity Classic where he was three strokes better than Bubba Watson and Scott Gutschewski. Added a second victory four years later when he won the Panama Movistar Championship by one stroke over Jeff Klauk and Arjun Atwal...Also spent part of his early career on the Southern Africa Tour where he finished second on that Tour's Order of Merit in 1999 which included a victory at the Dimension Data Pro-Am and a runner-up finish at the South African Open Championship...Has also made numerous starts on the European Tour, the Canadian Tour and in numerous South American events where he won five times...Led the Canadian Tour in scoring average in 1995 and finished second on that circuit's Order of Merit which included a win at the Canadian Masters. One year earlier he won the Canadian Tour's Manitoba Open...Played collegiately at the University of Florida, where he won All-SEC and All-American honors in 1985.
tourBios.personal: Sister, Page, is former LPGA member and former women's golf coach at Vanderbilt...Enjoys discussing politics...Was valedictorian of his high school graduating class. Lists former President Ronald Reagan as his hero...Got his start in golf from his dad at age 8...Attended Sarasota High School...Bucket list includes attending soccer's World Cup...Favorite quote is "Often wrong, seldom in doubt." Would love to guest host "Squawk Box" on CNBC..Has won professional events in six countries.

dyn.dynResults: His best finish on the PGA TOUR Champions in 2016 is 2nd at the Mississippi Gulf Resort Classic presented by C Spire.
dyn.dynStats: He ranks 7th in Scoring Average (Actual) on the PGA TOUR Champions.
